cards.kikuyu: Ndo- | Two- | **Ndokĩra** dagĩka ikũmi ciathira. (I started ten minutes ago.) | **Do**kĩra | | | | | **Twokĩra** dagĩka ikũmi ciathira. (We started ten minutes ago.) | **Two**kĩra | | **2nd Person** (You Sg./You Pl.) | Wo- | Mwo- | **Wokĩra** dagĩka ikũmi ciathira. (You started ten minutes ago.) | **Wo**kĩra | | | | | **Mwokĩra** dagĩka ikũmi ciathira. (You all started ten minutes ago.) | **Mwo**kĩra | | **3rd Person** (He/She/They) | O- | Mo- | **Okĩra** dagĩka ikũmi ciathira. (He/She started ten minutes ago.) | **O**kĩra | | | | | **Mokĩra** dagĩka ikũmi ciathira. (They started ten minutes ago.) | **Mo**kĩra | --- ### Past Tense

cards.kikuyu: Ndi- | Twi- | **Ndĩthambire** na maĩ mahoro. (I washed/showered with warm water.) | **Ndĩthambire** | | | | | **Twĩthambire** na maĩ mahoro. (We washed/showered with warm water.) | **Twĩthambire** | | **2nd Person** (You Sg./You Pl.) | Wĩ- | Mwĩ- | **Wĩthambire** na maĩ mahoro. (You washed/showered with warm water.) | **Wĩthambire** | | | | | **Mwĩthambire** na maĩ mahoro. (You all washed/showered with warm water.) | **Mwĩthambire** | | **3rd Person** (He/She/They) | E- | Me- | **Ethambire** na maĩ mahoro. (He/She washed/showered with warm water.) | **Ethambire** | | | | | **Methambire** na maĩ mahoro. (They washed/showered with warm water.) | **Methambire** | *** **Learn Kĩkũyũ

cards.english: Kaĩ ũrakorora? Tua gĩkorora | Why are you snorting? Blow your nose. | | **Kĩmako** | WORRIED | **Gũathĩmũra** - Nyita kanua ũgĩathĩmũra | Cover your mouth when sneezing. | | **Kũhahũka** | SURPRISED | **Gũkomba** | to make bad gestures at someone who is facing away; To borrow money | | **Ũrĩmũ** | SILLY | **Kũigua Kĩnyĩria** | to be disgusted | | **Kwaga kũiganĩra** | FRUSTRATED | **Kũnyĩra** | to express disgust for something
cards.kikuyu: Ndiratwara mwana thibitarĩ tondũ nĩ arahaya | I am taking the child to the hospital because he is groaning. | | **Ndũhĩo** | EXCITED | **Gũkorora**

cards.kikuyu: Ndongu ndũrũ - a bitter sodom apple. In English we say A good boy In Kikuyu we say Boy good. Mũĩrĩtu Use the list any of the adjective roots and the 4 nouns below to make sentences similar nĩ these ones. Mũĩrĩtu ũyũ mwega nĩ wanyu - this good girl is yours Aĩrĩtu aya ega nĩ a o (...ao)

cards.kikuyu: Nda/ Nda | | **hand** | Rũhĩ/ Hĩ | | **waist** | Njohero/ Njohero | | **knee** | Îru/ Maru | | **fingers** | Kĩara/ Twara | | **leg** | Kũgũrũ/ Magũrũ | | **foot** | Ikĩnya/ Makĩnya | | **toes** | Kĩara/ Twara | *** ## Nuclear Family and Dialogue This vocabulary and dialogue are taken from the image illustrating the family: | Kikuyu Phrase | English Translation | Context/Notes | |:---|:---|:---| | **Ũyũ nĩ baba** | This is father | Father is taking photographs. | | **Ũyũ ũngĩ nĩ maitũ** | This other one is mother | | | **Tũrũgamĩte na mwarĩ wa maitũ** | We are standing with my sister | Literally: "We are standing with the daughter of my mother." | | **Ũcio mũraihu nĩ mama** | The tall one is my uncle (mother's side) | **Mama** refers to the maternal uncle. | | **Baba arahũra mbica** | Father is taking photographs | | | **Mwarimũ:** Maina rũgama | **Teacher:** Maina, stand up | | | **Maina:** Nĩ ndarũgama mwarimũ | **Maina:** I have stood up teacher | | | **Mwarimũ:** Ũyũ nũũ ? | **Teacher:** Who is this | Asking about the father. | | **Maina:** Ũyũ nĩ baba | **Maina:** This is father | | | **Mwarimũ:** Ũyũ ũngĩ nĩ nũũ ? | **Teacher:** Who is this other one? | Asking about the mother. | | **Maina:** Ũyũ ũngĩ nĩ maitũ | **Maina:** This other one is mother | | | **Mwarimũ:** Mũrũgamĩte naũ? | **Teacher:** Who are you standing with? | | | **Maina:** Tũrũgamĩte na Mwarĩ wa maitũ | **Maina:** We are standing with my sister | | | **Mwarimũ:** Ĩkara thĩ | **Teacher:** Sit down | | *** *The vertical text on both images reads: **Learn Kikuyu
cards.context: Verb conjugation - Other - Verb conjugation: conjugation example - File 166
cards.cultural_notes: Native speaker verb conjugation from Easy Kikuyu lessons by Emmanuel Kariuki. Native speaker verb conjugation examples from Easy Kikuyu lessons This example demonstrates other conjugation patterns in natural Kikuyu speech, showing authentic usage and proper morphological structure.

cards.kikuyu: Nda/ Nda | | **hand** | Rũhĩ/ Hĩ | | **waist** | Njohero/ Njohero | | **knee** | Îru/ Maru | | **fingers** | Kĩara/ Twara | | **leg** | Kũgũrũ/ Magũrũ | | **foot** | Ikĩnya/ Makĩnya | | **toes** | Kĩara/ Twara | *** ## 2. Health and Hospital Phrases This section provides vocabulary and common phrases related to illness and visiting a hospital (**Thibitarĩ**). ### Vocabulary | Kikuyu Term | English Meaning | Image Context | |:---|:---|:---| | **Thibitarĩ** | Hospital | Building exterior | | **Mũrwaru** | Patient / Sick person | Person on a hospital bed | | **Ndagĩtarĩ** | Doctor (male) | Man in a lab coat | | **Mũrigitani** | Doctor (female/general term) | Woman in a lab coat | | **Dagĩtarĩ wa magego** | Dentist | Person sitting in a dental chair | | **Mĩthaiga** | Medicine / Drugs | Pills and bottles | | **Ndawa** | Medicine / Remedy | Pills and bottles | ### Dialogue and Phrases | Kikuyu Phrase | English Translation | |:---|:---| | **Ndĩ mũrwaru** | I am sick | | **Ndiraiguia wega** | I am not feeling well | | **Thĩĩ thibitarĩ** | Go to the hospital | | **Ũraatũũrwo nĩ kũ?** | Where are you hurting (where is your pain)? | | **Ndiraatũũrwo nĩ mũtwee** | I have a headache | | **Nĩ ũraatũũrwo nĩ nda?** | Do you have a stomachache? | | **Aca ndiraatũũrwo nĩ nda** | No I do not have a stomachache | | **Ũraatũũrwo nĩ kũũ ũngĩ?** | Where else are you hurting? | | **O na igego nĩ rĩraatũũra** | I also have a toothache | | **Thĩĩ wone ndagĩtarĩ wa magego** | Go see a dentist | | **Eha mũrigitanĩ** | Where is the nurse? | | **Amba ũthĩmwo ratirĩ** | Get your weight checked first | | **Hĩĩ! Wĩ na ũrugarĩ!** | Wah! Your temperature is high | *** *The vertical text on both images reads: **Learn Kikuyu
cards.context: Verb conjugation - Other - Verb conjugation: conjugation example - File 170
cards.cultural_notes: Native speaker verb conjugation from Easy Kikuyu lessons by Emmanuel Kariuki. Native speaker verb conjugation examples from Easy Kikuyu lessons This example demonstrates other conjugation patterns in natural Kikuyu speech, showing authentic usage and proper morphological structure.

cards.english: Hospital** **Ĩno nĩ thibitarĩ** - this is a hospital **Thibitarĩ nĩ nyũmba nene** - A hospital is a big building **Ũyũ nĩ mũrwaru** - This is a patient **Ũyũ nĩ nđagĩtarĩ** - This is a doctore **Ũyũ nĩ mũrigitani** - This is a nurse **Ũyũ nake nĩ nđagĩtarĩ wa magego** - and this one is a dentist **Ici nĩ nđawa** - These are medicine **Nđawa ya mbũrũgũtũ** - tablet
cards.kikuyu: Ndagĩtarĩ - **Doctore** Mũrigitani - **Nurse** Dagĩtarĩ wa magego - **Dentist** Mĩthaiga Nđawa - **Medicine** --- **Thibitarĩ

cards.english: Doctor * **Mũrigitani** - Nurse * **Nđawa ya mbũrũgũtũ** - tablet #### Hygiene * **Wĩthambe moko** - Wash your hands * **Wĩhake thabuni** - Apply soap * **Wĩhuure na ngacibũ ya karatathi** - Dry with a clean towel

cards.kikuyu: Ndirica ya keerĩ** | The second window | **ya** (for N- class nouns) | | **Cabi ya gatatũ** | The third cap | **ya** (for Cĩ- / N- class nouns) | | **Metha ya kana** | The fourth table | **ya** (for N- class nouns) | | **Nyoni ya gatano** | The fifth bird | **ya** (for N- class nouns) | | **thamaki ya gatandatũ** | The sixth fish | **ya** (for N- class nouns) | | **Ibuku rĩa mũgwanja** | The seventh book | **rĩa** (for Rĩ- / Ma- class nouns) | | **Itimũ rĩa kanana** | The eighth spear | **rĩa** (for Rĩ- / Ma- class nouns) | | **Icembe rĩa Kenda** | The ninth hoe | **rĩa** (for Rĩ- / Ma- class nouns) | | **Mbaathi ya Ikũmi** | The tenth bus | **ya** (for N- class nouns) | | **Gĩkombe kĩa mbere** | The first cup | **kĩa** (for Gĩ- / Cĩ- class nouns) | | **Ngirathi ya keerĩ** | The second glass | **ya** (for N- class nouns) | | **Gĩciko gĩa gatatũ** | The third spoon | **gĩa** (for Gĩ- / Cĩ- class nouns) | | **Mũbira wa kana** | The fourth ball | **wa** (for Mũ- / Mĩ- class nouns) | | **Nyũmba ya gatano** | The fifth house | **ya** (for N- class nouns) | | **Kĩratũ gĩa gatandatũ** | The sixth shoe | **gĩa** (for Kĩ- / Cĩ- class nouns) | | **Karamu ka mũgwanja** | The seventh pen (or *small pen*) | **ka** (for Ka- / Tũ- class nouns) | | **Gĩtĩ gĩa kanana** | The eighth chair | **gĩa** (for Gĩ- / Cĩ- class nouns) | | **Mũĩrĩtu wa Kenda** | The ninth girl | **wa** (for Mũ- / A- class nouns) | | **thaani ya Ikũmi** | The tenth plate | **ya** (for N- class nouns) | *** **Learn Kĩkũyũ
cards.context: Verb conjugation - Other - Verb conjugation: conjugation example - File 231
cards.cultural_notes: Native speaker verb conjugation from Easy Kikuyu lessons by Emmanuel Kariuki. Native speaker verb conjugation examples from Easy Kikuyu lessons This example demonstrates other conjugation patterns in natural Kikuyu speech, showing authentic usage and proper morphological structure.

cards.kikuyu: Ndigũkwĩra ũrĩa njĩtagwo** | I will not tell you my name | 1st Person Singular Future Negative (*Ndi-gũ...*) | | **Nĩ waragia Gĩkũyũ?** | Do you speak Kĩkũyũ? | Question (Present Tense) | | **Ndiaragia Gĩkũyũ o na hanini** | I don't speak Kĩkũyũ (even a little) | 1st Person Singular Present Negative (*Ndi-a...*) | | **Mũgai nĩ aragia Gĩkũyũ?** | Does Mũgai speak...? | Question (Present Tense) | | **Mũgai ndaragia Gĩkũyũ** | Mũgai does not speak Kĩkũyũ | 3rd Person Singular Present Negative (*Nda-ra...*) | | **O na Gĩthweri tũtĩaragia** | Even Swahili we do not speak (We also don't speak Swahili) | 1st Person Plural Present Negative (*Tũ-tĩ-a...*) | | **Aria kahora** | Speak slowly | Positive imperative (Command) | | **Ndĩkwaria kahora** | I will not speak slowly | 1st Person Singular Future Negative (*Ndi-kũ...*) | | **Tũtĩkwaria Kahora** | We will not speak slowly | 1st Person Plural Future Negative (*Tũ-tĩ-kũ...*) | | **Atĩ mũtĩkwaria kahora?** | So you will not ......? (So you all will not speak slowly?) | 2nd Person Plural Future Negative Question (*Mũ-tĩ-kũ...*) | | **Moiga matĩkwaria kahora** | They have said they will not speak slowly | 3rd Person Plural Future Negative (*Ma-tĩ-kũ...*) | | **O na wee ndũkwaria kahora?** | Even you, you will not speak slowly? | 2nd Person Singular Future Negative Question (*Ndũ-kũ...*) | | **Thĩĩ mũciĩ na ihenya** | Go home fast (Quickly) | Positive imperative (Command) | | **Ndigũthĩĩ** | I will not go. | 1st Person Singular Future Negative (*Ndi-gũ...*) | *** **Learn Kĩkũyũ
cards.context: Verb conjugation - Other - Verb conjugation: conjugation example - File 232
cards.cultural_notes: Native speaker verb conjugation from Easy Kikuyu lessons by Emmanuel Kariuki. Native speaker verb conjugation examples from Easy Kikuyu lessons This example demonstrates other conjugation patterns in natural Kikuyu speech, showing authentic usage and proper morphological structure.

cards.english: Nyita kanua ũgĩathĩmũra | To sneeze. Cover your mouth when sneezing. | | **Gũkomba** - ũrakomba mũndũ nĩkĩ? | To make bad gestures/to borrow. Why are you making a bad gesture at a person? | | **Kũigua Kĩnyiria** - Araigua kĩnyĩria ona ndinĩhoho | To be disgusted/nauseated. He/She feels disgusted even though he/she is not drunk. | | **Kũnyĩra** - Maranyĩra irio cia mũcaina | To express disgust for food. They are expressing disgust for the Chinese food. | | **Kũnunũha** - Ndanunũha, ndakoma na ngara | To nose bleed. He has a nosebleed, he is sleeping on a sheet/mat. | | **Gũĩthĩkĩra** - Aigua mũndũ akua, ethĩkĩra | To have a sad posture/to mourn. He/She hears a person has died, he/she sits sadly. | | **Gwĩthĩkĩra nĩũndũ wa kĩeha kĩingĩ** | To have a sad posture due to much sorrow. | --- ## Verb Conjugation Exercise To fulfill the instruction, we will conjugate the verb stems into the **Past Tense

cards.english: I}$ class) | | **Mũkanda** | **rope** | | **Yohetwo na muuto** | **It has been tied with pillows.** | --- ## Grammar Highlights The example sentence is great for illustrating several key features of Kikuyu
cards.kikuyu: Ndigiri ĩno nĩ ya Wajir** * **Translation:** This donkey is from Wajir; It is found in Wajir; it belongs to Wajir. * **Nĩmũrona ũrĩa ĩmenye-reirwo do you (all) see** * **Translation:** Do you (all) see how it has been taken care of? --- ### Key Vocabulary and Grammar | Kikuyu Word/Phrase | Literal Meaning/Grammar Note | | :--- | :--- | | **Ndigiri** | **Donkey** (The authentic Kikuyu word; *Bunda* or *Ng'unda* are also used by some people) | | **Ĩno** | **This one** (Demonstrative for noun class N/N $\rightarrow$ **ici** is the plural: **These ones**) | | **Nĩ ũrona?** | **Can you see? Do you see?** (Singular) | | **Nĩmũrona** | **Do you (all) see** (Plural) | | **Ũrĩa** | **How** (In this context only) | | **Nĩ ũrona ũrĩa...** | **Do you see how....** | | **Kũmenyerera** | **to take care** | | **Menyerera** | **take care of** | | **Ũrĩa ĩmenyerereirwo** | **how it has been cared for** (Uses the passive voice **-irwo**) | | **Wimenyerere** | **take care of yourself** (Uses the reflexive prefix **-i-**) | | **Wega** | **well; good** | | **Oha** | **tie** | | **Mĩohe** | **tie it** (Command) | | **Ohetwo** | **he has been tied** (Passive voice) | | **Yohetwo** | **it has been tied** (Passive voice, applied to the donkey, which falls under the $\text{I
